org.kawanfw.sql.api.server

Class SshAuthDatabaseConfigurator

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.kawanfw.sql.api.server.DefaultDatabaseConfigurator
      • org.kawanfw.sql.api.server.SshAuthDatabaseConfigurator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DatabaseConfigurator

    public class SshAuthDatabaseConfigurator
extends DefaultDatabaseConfigurator
implements DatabaseConfigurator
    A concrete DatabaseConfigurator that extends DefaultDatabaseConfigurator and allows zero-code client (username, password) authentication using SSH.
    Author:
    Nicolas de Pomereu

    • Method Detail

      • login

        public boolean login(String username,
            char[] password,
            String database,
            String ipAddress)
              throws IOException
        Allows using SSH to authenticate the remote (username, password) couple sent by the client side.
        • If the user.home/.kawansoft/sshAuth.properties file exists:
          the (username, password) couple is checked against the SSH server of the host defined with the properties host for the hostname and port for the port in the user.home/.kawansoft/sshAuth.properties file.
        • If sshAuth.properties file does not exists:
          the host IP is used as hostname value and port is 22.
        user.home is the one of the running servlet container.

        Specified by:
        login in interface DatabaseConfigurator
        Overrides:
        login in class DefaultDatabaseConfigurator
        Parameters:
        username - the username sent by the client login
        password - the password to connect to the server
        database - the database name to which the client wants to connect
        ipAddress - the IP address of the client user
        Returns:
        true if the (login, password) couple is correct/valid as a SSH user on this host. If false, the client side will not be authorized to send any command.
        Throws:
        IOException - if wrapped Ssh.login(String, char[]) throws an I/O Exception.

AceQL HTTP - library of REST like APIs that allow to access to remote SQL databases from any device that supports http.
DB2 - Informix - Ingres - MySQL - Oracle Database - PostgreSQL - SQL Server - Sybase - Teradata
